SPEAKER: NARRATOR
TEXT: HAMLET, PRINCE OF DENMARK

SPEAKER: SCENE
TEXT: ACT I

SPEAKER: SCENE
TEXT: SCENE I. Elsinore. A platform before the Castle.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Enter Francisco and Barnardo, two sentinels.

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: Who's there?

SPEAKER: FRANCISCO
TEXT: Nay, answer me. Stand and unfold yourself.

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: Long live the King!

SPEAKER: FRANCISCO
TEXT: Barnardo?

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: He.

SPEAKER: FRANCISCO
TEXT: You come most carefully upon your hour.

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: 'Tis now struck twelve. Get thee to bed, Francisco.

SPEAKER: FRANCISCO
TEXT: For this relief much thanks. 'Tis bitter cold, and I am sick at heart.

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: Have you had quiet guard?

SPEAKER: FRANCISCO
TEXT: Not a mouse stirring.

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: Well, good night. If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus, the rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.

SPEAKER: FRANCISCO
TEXT: I think I hear them. Stand, ho! Who is there?

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Enter Horatio and Marcellus.

SPEAKER: HORATIO
TEXT: Friends to this ground.

SPEAKER: MARCELLUS
TEXT: And liegemen to the Dane.

SPEAKER: FRANCISCO
TEXT: Give you good night.

SPEAKER: MARCELLUS
TEXT: O, farewell, honest soldier. Who hath reliev'd you?

SPEAKER: FRANCISCO
TEXT: Barnardo has my place. Give you good-night.

SPEAKER: MARCELLUS
TEXT: Holla, Barnardo!

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: Say, what, is Horatio there?

SPEAKER: HORATIO
TEXT: A piece of him.

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: Welcome, Horatio. Welcome, good Marcellus.

SPEAKER: MARCELLUS
TEXT: What, has this thing appear'd again tonight?

SPEAKER: BARNARDO
TEXT: I have seen nothing.

SPEAKER: MARCELLUS
TEXT: Horatio says 'tis but our fantasy, and will not let belief take hold of him.

SPEAKER: SCENE
TEXT: SCENE V. A more remote part of the Castle.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Enter Ghost and Hamlet.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: Whither wilt thou lead me? Speak, I'll go no further.

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: Mark me.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: I will.

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: My hour is almost come, when I to sulph'rous and tormenting flames must render up myself.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: Alas, poor ghost!

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: Pity me not, but lend thy serious hearing to what I shall unfold.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: Speak, I am bound to hear.

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: So art thou to revenge, when thou shalt hear.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: What?

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: I am thy father's spirit, doom'd for a certain term to walk the night.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: O God!

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: But that I am forbid to tell the secrets of my prison-house, I could a tale unfold whose lightest word would harrow up thy soul.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: Murder?

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: Murder most foul, as in the best it is, but this most foul, strange, and unnatural.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: Haste me to know't, that I with wings as swift as meditation or the thoughts of love may sweep to my revenge.

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: Now, Hamlet, hear. 'Tis given out that, sleeping in my orchard, a serpent stung me. But know, thou noble youth, the serpent that did sting thy father's life now wears his crown.

SPEAKER: HAMLET
TEXT: O my prophetic soul! My uncle!

SPEAKER: GHOST
TEXT: Ay, that incestuous, that adulterate beast.
